Carlos A Morris Wastewater Treatment Plant

RMP Plan Executive Summary

Executive Summary

This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk Management Progrom (RMP) and the associated policies at the Carlos A Morris Wastewater Treatment Plant, one of two facilities owned by the Pichard Water and Sewer Board and operated by Optech.

Prevention and Response Policies

Optech believes that it is important to provide a safe workplace to its employees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, Optech has developed proactive safety and environment programs, which are reliant upon active employee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems.  Optech has determined that the OSHA Process Safety Management standard also applies to the personnel at the Carlos A Morris WWTP and therefore has prepared this RMP to comply with the RMP Program 3 requirements.  By doing so, Optech affirms its proactive and environmental philosophy and acknowledges the inherent value of full RMP compliance.

The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Its program elements require the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of regulated chemicals.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no release would occur.  Accoordingly, a wel-developed and properly implemented prevention program will lower the possibility release and minimize the consequence of a release should on occur.

Optech takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at all of the two facilities it operates by ensuring that its employees are well-informed requarding the hazards associated with re

requlated processes (e.g., chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Carlos A Morris WWTP) and actively participated in comprehensive process hazard analyses.  The employees that work on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems are properly trained in the safe operation of the covered processes and the safe handling of treatment chemicals.  They are aided in this work by complete, understandable system operating procedures.

Optech management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents that may have an affect on the surrounding community.  This understanding is reflected in procedures described system operating procedures.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Carlos A Morris WWTP is located at 54 Grover Street, in Pichard, Moble County, Alabama.  The Carlos A Morris WWTP treats wastewater through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations.  This acitvated sludge plant has anaerobic digester, drying beds, primary and secondary clarification.  Average design flow is 4.0 MGD, with peak capacity of 9.0 MGD.  Sludge is transported to a landfill site by a separate contractor.  Optech developed an equipment repair program and an ongoing training program.  The Carlos A Morris WWTP utilizes chlorine as a biocide in the treatment of wastewater.  The chlorine is stored in one-ton containers with a maximum intended inventory of three containers ( 6,000 pounds ) on site.  In addition, the Carlos A Morris WWTP utilizes sulfur dioxide for the dechlorination of treated effluent.  The sulfur dioxide is stored in one- ton containers with a maximum intended inventory of four containers ( 8,000 pounds) on site.  Therefore, the Carlos A Morris WWTP is requlated under the RMP rule due to the volume of chlorine and sulfur dioxide store and used at the facility.

Prevention Steps for Chlorine

The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP manual.

The prevention program includes the following elements:

* Process safety information, which includes information pertaining to the hazards of chlorine in the process, process technology, and process equipment.

* Process hazard analysis (PHA), which includes a systematic evaluation (by an employee team) of:  the hazards of the chlorine process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and administrative controls, consequences o failure of the engineering controls, facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health efects of failure of controls.

* Operating procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

* Training for each Carlos A Morris WWTP employee involved in operating the chlorine system.

* Mechanical integrity procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the chlorine process equipment.

* Management of changes procedures to manage changes (other than "replacements in kind") to the chlorine system.

* Pre-startup safety review for additions or significant modifications to the chlorine process, or any new requlated chemical process.

* Compliance audits at least every three years form 1999 to evaluate Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP compliance.

* Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of chlorine from the Carlos A Morris WWTP.

* Employee participation in the development in implementation of the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP, and employee access to RMP information.

* Hot work prohibition policy on or near the chlorine system when chlorine is present in the affected section of the process.

* Contractor management program, to ensure appropriate evaluation and section of qualified contractors for work on or near the chlorine system, proper notification of contractors regarding known chlorine system hazards and the Carlos A M

orris WWTP emergency plan.  Limited access to the chlorine process, and evaluation of contractor performance.

In addition to these elements, the chlorine storage area and chlorine feed room at the Carlos A Morris WWTP are equipped with chlorine leak detection devices that continuously monitor the air for chlorine gas.  If the chlorine sensor detects a specified level, audio alarms will be activated and a high rate ventilation system can be activated in the chlorine feed room.  The ventilation system withdraws chlorine and air from a low elevation in the storage room to a safe outdoor location.  The alarm systems are maintained and tested on a reqular basis to ensure proper operation should there be a chlorine release.  Management of changes procedures will be used for the upgrades to the chlorine system.

Prevention Steps for Sulfur Dioxide

The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP manual.  The prevention program includes the following elements:

* Process safety information, which includes information pertaining to the hazards of sulfur dioxide in the process, process technology, and process equipment.

* Process hazard analysis (PHA), which includes a systematic evaluation (by an employee team) of:  the hazards of the sulfur dioxide process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and administrative controls, consequences o failure of the engineering controls, facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health efects of failure of controls.

* Operating procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

* Training for each Carlos A Morris WWTP employee involved in operating the sulfur dioxide system.

* Mechanical integrity procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the sulfur dioxide process equipment.

* Management of changes procedures to manage chang

es (other than "replacements in kind") to the sulfur dioxide system.

* Pre-startup safety review for additions or significant modifications to the sulfur dioxide process, or any new requlated chemical process.

* Compliance audits at least every three years form 1999 to evaluate Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP compliance.

* Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of sulfur dioxide from the Carlos A Morris WWTP.

* Employee participation in the development in implementation of the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP, and employee access to RMP information.

* Hot work prohibition policy on or near the sulfur dioxide system when sulfur dioxide is present in the affected section of the process.

* Contractor management program, to ensure appropriate evaluation and section of qualified contractors for work on or near the sulfur dioxide system, proper notification of contractors regarding known sulfur dioxide system hazards and the Carlos A Morris WWTP emergency plan.  Limited access to the sulfur dioxide process, and evaluation of contractor performance.

In addition to these elements, the sulfur dioxide storage area and sulfur dioxide feed room at the Carlos A Morris WWTP are equipped with sulfur dioxide leak detection devices that continuously monitor the air for sulfur dioxide gas.  If the sulfur dioxide sensor detects a specified level, audio alarms will be activated and a high rate ventilation system can be activated in the sulfur dioxide feed room.  The ventilation system withdraws sulfur dioxide and air from a low elevation in the storage room to a safe outdoor location.  The alarm systems are maintained and tested on a reqular basis to ensure proper operation should there be a sulfur dioxide release.  Management of changes procedures will be used for the upgrades to the sulfur dioxide system.

Accident History

Within the five-year period prior to the submittal of the

RMP, there were no accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide meeting the requirements of 40 CFR 68.42.

Emergency Response Program

This facility has established and maintains and emergency response program that is coordinated with local response agencies, including the Moblie Fire Department.  The program is decribed in detail in the Carlos A Morris WWTP RMP manual and meets the requirements of 40 CFR 68.95, which included facility notification of emergency responders and evacuation.  The goals of the program are to protect onsite employees from hazardous effects of chemical releases and to minimize the effect of releases on the general public.  The program is routinely reviewed and updated to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.

Planned Changes for Improved Safety

Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employes.  Employee meeting that focus on safety issues are held regularly at the Carlos A Morris WWTP.  Employees are encouraged and trained to recongnize hazard and to present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.

As part of the development of the Carlos A Morris WWTP program, process hazard analyses were conducted with key employees to meet the prevention program requirements.  During these sessions, recommendations were made for the purpose of improving safety and preventing accidental chemical releases.  Each recommendation has been or will be considered for implementation.  Through not all recommendations may be implemented, all will be considered.  The exeercise has provided all a affected employees with a heightened awareness of safety issues ralated to the covered process.
